description.content: This API returns all transactions associated with merchant. This included transactions Initialized and Disbursed both.

header.description: (Required) An API key is a string value passed by a client app to the API proxies. The key uniquely identifies the client app.
(Required) Epoch timestamp in the request initiating system

(Required) Contains a unique ID generated by the client that can be used for enforcing idempotency on POST actions. POSTs are inherently non-idempotent and submitting the exact same request multiple times would create duplicate resources. Note:- Omitting this header increases the risk of duplicate transactions, which for payments could cost the client issues like double-billing.

response.name: Transactions response - Success

header.description: (Required) An API key is a string value passed by a client app to the API proxies. The key uniquely identifies the client app.
(Required) Epoch timestamp in the request initiating system
(Required) Authorization information for the request. Format- `HMAC {hmacToken}`

(Required) Contains a unique ID generated by the client that can be used for enforcing idempotency on POST actions. POSTs are inherently non-idempotent and submitting the exact same request multiple times would create duplicate resources. Note:- Omitting this header increases the risk of duplicate transactions, which for payments could cost the client issues like double-billing.
(Required) used to indicate the media type of the resource.

description.content: This API returns all transactions associated with recipient. This included transactions Initialized and Disbursed both.

variable.description: (Required) Unique Id associated with recipient while set up.The value can be MerchantCustomerId or RecipientId.Merchant provision through Apigee should always pass MerchantCustomerId.

header.description: (Required) An API key is a string value passed by a client app to the API proxies. The key uniquely identifies the client app.
(Required) Epoch timestamp in the request initiating system

(Required) Contains a unique ID generated by the client that can be used for enforcing idempotency on POST actions. POSTs are inherently non-idempotent and submitting the exact same request multiple times would create duplicate resources. Note:- Omitting this header increases the risk of duplicate transactions, which for payments could cost the client issues like double-billing.

description.content: This Specification document lists the APIs required to fetch historical transactions.
